options.text: To break down food into smaller particles

options.text: To siphon off most of the water from the stool

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: The impostor syndrome

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of the Impostor Syndrome, according to the transcript?

options.text: Feeling anxious and uncertain about one's abilities

options.label: B
options.text: Having a hugely unhelpful picture of what other people are really like

options.label: D
options.text: Lacking confidence in one's skills and knowledge

options.text: In the workplace, where people feel pressure to perform

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: In social media, where people compare themselves to others

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: We know both ourselves and others from the outside

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: To show that even great people have bodily functions

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: A
options.text: A hospital room with a beautiful view.

options.label: B
options.text: A cottage community designed specifically for the chronically homeless.

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: He showed a colorful image and then suddenly changed it to black and white.

options.label: B
options.text: He showed a black and white image and then suddenly changed it to color.

options.label: C
options.text: He showed a black and white image and asked viewers to focus on a specific part of it, then changed the image to color without moving their eyes.

options.label: D
options.text: He showed a colorful image and asked viewers to focus on a specific part of it, then changed the image to black and white without moving their eyes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the device that Greg created, which uses LEDs to create images?

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above (the device doesn't have a specific name mentioned in the transcript)

multiple-choice.question: How does Greg control the LEDs on his device to create images?

options.label: A
options.text: He uses a microcontroller to individually control each LED.

options.label: B
options.text: He uses a DC motor to spin the LEDs and create a persistence of vision effect.

options.label: C
options.text: He uses a combination of a microcontroller and a DC motor to control the LEDs and create images.

options.label: D
options.text: He uses a computer program to upload images to the device.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term that Greg uses to describe the individual units of light on his device?
Why does Destin's brain continue to see the light from the LEDs even when they are not illuminated?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the persistence of vision effect, which causes the eye to average what it sees over a short period of time.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the high speed of the LEDs, which creates a strobe effect.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the brightness of the LEDs, which overwhelms the eye.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the distance between the LEDs, which creates a gap in the image.

multiple-choice.question: According to Dr. Stuart Anstis, what is the delay time between when the LED is illuminated and when the eye registers the light?
What is the effect of the eye's moving average on our perception of light?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates a gap in the image when the light is not illuminated.

options.label: B
options.text: It causes the light to appear brighter than it actually is.

options.label: C
options.text: It smooths out the image and creates a persistence of vision effect.

options.label: D
options.text: It creates a strobe effect when the light is flashing.

multiple-choice.question: At what rate would Destin expect to see a gap in the image instead of a uniform image?

options.label: A
options.text: If the average time is less than one revolution

options.label: B
options.text: If the average time is greater than one revolution

options.label: C
options.text: If the frame rate is less than 25 frames per second

options.label: D
options.text: If the frame rate is greater than 25 frames per second

multiple-choice.question: Why is the frame rate of video typically at least 25 frames per second?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it creates a persistence of vision effect that smooths out the image.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it creates a strobe effect that makes the image appear sharper.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is the minimum frame rate required to create a uniform image.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is the maximum frame rate that the human eye can process.

multiple-choice.question: According to Dr. Stuart Anstis, what is the trade-off that the eye makes in terms of time resolution and sensitivity to light?

options.label: A
options.text: The eye trades off time resolution for increased sensitivity to light.

options.label: B
options.text: The eye trades off sensitivity to light for increased time resolution.

options.label: C
options.text: The eye has a fixed time resolution and sensitivity to light.

options.label: D
options.text: The eye can adjust its time resolution and sensitivity to light independently.

title: Why are fish fish-shaped? - Lauren Sallan

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the way flying fish move through the water?

options.label: B
options.text: They leap out of the water and glide using wing-like fins.

options.label: C
options.text: They use a wave-like motion to generate speed.

options.label: D
options.text: They are slow swimmers and rely on camouflage for survival.

options.label: C
options.text: Their tails are attached by tendons to multiple muscles in their body.

options.label: D
options.text: They are slow swimmers and rely on camouflage for survival.

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They beat their wing-like median fins.

options.label: D
options.text: They are slow swimmers and rely on camouflage for survival.

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They use their flexible dorsal fins as makeshift tails.

options.label: D

options.text: Because they have proven successful for survival.

options.label: D

title: What causes headaches? - Dan Kwartler

multiple-choice.question: In ancient Greece, what was the name of the god of medicine that people prayed to for relief from headaches?

options.label: B
options.text: Primary headaches are caused by underlying diseases, while secondary headaches are not

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Migraines, tension headaches, and dehydration headaches

title: Stay in - or leave - a relationship?

options.label: C
options.text: Deciding whether to stay or leave a relationship

options.label: B
options.text: The state of their friends' relationships

options.label: A
options.text: Societal pressure to stay in a relationship

options.label: C
options.text: Religions insisting that God blessed unions

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Explaining how you feel and how sad you are

options.label: D
options.text: Talking about your favorite TV show

multiple-choice.question: What is one thing to consider when thinking about the potential consequences of leaving a relationship?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The risk of achieving no more than exchanging a familiar kind of unhappiness for a new and more complex variety of unhappiness

options.label: D
options.text: The possibility of moving to a new city

multiple-choice.question: What is the final advice given in the transcript for someone who still wants to leave a relationship after careful consideration?

options.label: A
options.text: Stay in the relationship and try to work things out

options.label: B
options.text: Leave the relationship immediately without looking back

options.label: C
options.text: Leave the relationship with a heavy heart and a cautious mind

options.label: D
